cards.title: TV Times's unseen portraits of celebrities
cards.rawTitle: TV Times's unseen portraits of celebrities

item.title: TV Times's unseen portraits of celebrities
item.trailText: Previously unseen and undated images of Ronnie Barker, Liza Minnelli and Woody Allen have been released after they were unearthed in an archive. The TV Times images were found in A4 envelopes packed up inside boxes at the British Film Institute (BFI) in London, after being stored there for more than 50 years. Only a tiny fraction were published before they were stashed away
item.standFirst: Previously unseen and undated images of Ronnie Barker, Liza Minnelli and Woody Allen have been released after they were unearthed in an archive. The TV Times images were found in A4 envelopes packed up inside boxes at the British Film Institute (BFI) in London, after being stored there for more than 50 years. Only a tiny fraction were published before they were stashed away

cards.title: Paris 'love locks' removed from Pont des Arts bridge
cards.rawTitle: Paris 'love locks' removed from Pont des Arts bridge

item.title: Paris 'love locks' removed from Pont des Arts bridge – in pictures
item.trailText: Paris’s famous bridge closes this week for the removal of brass ‘love locks’ purporting to symbolise the unending love of visiting tourists
item.standFirst: Paris’s famous bridge closes this week for the removal of brass locks purporting to symbolise the unending love of visiting tourists. A city hall campaign to save the bridges of Paris from the weight of hundreds of thousands of brass locks has not checked the ardour of droves of tourists, who continue to view it as the City of Love

displayImages.caption: A recently-married couple from Poland, Dominika and Bartek Mieczkowski, sit near an iron grill coered with ‘love locks’ on the Pont des Arts in Paris, France Photograph: John Schults/Reuters
displayImages.altText: A recently-married couple from Poland, Dominika and Bartek Mieczkowski, sit near an iron grill coered with "love locks" on the Pont de Arts in Paris, France.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A recently-married couple from Poland, Dominika and Bartek Mieczkowski, sit near an iron grill coered with ‘love locks’ on the Pont des Arts in Paris, France

cards.title: A world tour of breakdancing / Nas presents the Real Hip-Hop

item.title: Nas presents the Real Hip-Hop
item.trailText: Rapper Nasir 'Nas' Jones takes us on a world tour of breakdancing in the most unexpected places
item.standFirst:
Rapper Nasir 'Nas' Jones and director Adam Sjoberg take us on a world tour of breakdancing in the most unexpected places, as we visit the slums, shanty towns and ghettos of the world, where hip-hop really means something. With jaw-dropping breakdancing moves, b-boys and b-girls in Uganda, Yemen, Cambodia and Colombia give us an inspiring tribute to the uplifting power of music and movement

• Find out more about the full-length documentary Shake the Dust here
item.byline: Dan Susman, Jess Gormley, Juliet Riddell, Adam Sjoberg, Charlie Phillips and Bond 360

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Nas Presents Shake the Dust: The Real Hip Hop - video Photograph: guardian.co.uk

cards.title: How to clean up the murky world of palm oil
cards.rawTitle: How to clean up the murky world of palm oil

item.title: How to clean up the murky world of palm oil
item.trailText:
It's one of the world's most popular commodities, found in 50% of consumer goods products, including chocolate, lipstick and body lotion. Yet its production often comes at a cost to local communities, forests and the wider environment.

Here we ask three experts what companies can do to bring us more sustainable palm oil that does not cause long-term ecological damage and benefits local communities.
item.standFirst:
It's one of the world's most popular commodities, found in 50% of consumer goods products, including chocolate, lipstick and body lotion. Yet its production often comes at a cost to local communities, forests and the wider environment.

Here we ask three experts what companies can do to bring us more sustainable palm oil that does not cause long-term ecological damage and benefits local communities.

Once you've had a listen, check out our podcast of the live experts debate held at the Guardian for more in depth insight into the murky world of palm oil

displayImages.altText: Animation

sublinks.title: Sustainable palm oil / Where do we go from here?
sublinks.rawTitle: Where do we go from here?

item.title: Sustainable palm oil: where do we go from here?
item.trailText: We invited experts from Greenpeace International, the Environmental Investigation Agency, WWF and RSPO to the Guardian to debate one of the world's most popular commodities: palm oil.
item.standFirst: We invited experts from Greenpeace International, the Environmental Investigation Agency, WWF and RSPO to the Guardian to debate one of the world's most popular commodities: palm oil.
item.body: What can companies do? Are certification schemes working? How does the consumer fit into this and what does sustainable palm oil mean anyway? Our panelists debated these questions and more, so have a listen and let us know what you think in the comment space below.

displayImages.altText: Woman watering palm oil plants

cards.title: California teeming / Skydivers set record with 119-person formation

item.title: Skydivers set new Australian record with 119-person formation
item.trailText: Late on Sunday afternoon, 119 skydivers broke the Australian record for free-fall large formation over California
item.standFirst: Late on Sunday afternoon, 119 skydivers broke the Australian record for free-fall large formation over California. Team captain Greg Jack talks about the achievement at Perris Valley, which breaks the record of 112 set in 2010. The participants, aged from 21-66, jumped from seven aircraft from an altitude of 19,000 feet (5,800 metres)

stillImage.caption: 119 Australian skydivers breaking world record for formation free-fall over California. 02 June 2015 Photograph: AAP Photograph: AAP
stillImage.cleanCaption: 119 Australian skydivers breaking world record for formation free-fall over California. 02 June 2015 Photograph: AAP

item.title: Giro d'Italia 2015: stages 16 to 21
item.trailText: With Alberto Contador’s win concluding the 2015 Giro d’Italia, we take a look at some of the best images from the final six stages
item.standFirst:
With Alberto Contador’s triumph concluding the 2015 Giro d’Italia, we take a look at some of the best images from the final six stages.

Click here for images from Stages 10 to 15 and here for images from Stages one to nine

displayImages.caption: Stage 16 Pinzolo - Aprica (174km) The Trek Factory Racing team warm up for the day’s racing. Photograph: Tim de Waele/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Stage 16 Pinzolo - Aprica (174km)  Trek Factory Racing Team warm up ahead of the day's racing
displayImages.cleanCaption: Stage 16 Pinzolo - Aprica (174km) The Trek Factory Racing team warm up for the day’s racing.

displayImages.caption: Fabio Aru is cheered on as he climbs one of the stage’s five Italian Alpine peaks. The Italian struggled with the stage, losing another two minutes to Alberto Contador. Photograph: Tim de Waele/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Fabio Aru is cheered on as he climbs one of the stages five Italian Alpine peaks.  The Italian struggled with the stage, losing another two minutes to Contador
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fabio Aru is cheered on as he climbs one of the stage’s five Italian Alpine peaks. The Italian struggled with the stage, losing another two minutes to Alberto Contador.

displayImages.caption: Contador kisses the pink jersey of overall leader on the podium. With Aru struggling with the stage, Contador increased his overall lead over the Italian and took a massive step towards his second Giro d’Italia triumph. An epic 16th stage was won by fellow Mikel Landa in a time of 5hr 2min 51sec, with Contador settling for third place at 38sec behind on the wheel of Steven Kruijswijk. Photograph: Luk Benies/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Alberto Contador kisses the pink jersey of overall leader whilst on the podium. With Aru struggling with the stage Contador increased his overall lead over the Italian and took a massive step towards his second Giro d'Italia triumph. An epic 16th stage was won by fellow Mikel Landa in a time of 5hr 02min 51sec with Contador settling for third place at 38sec behind on the wheel of Steven Kruijswijk
displayImages.cleanCaption: Contador kisses the pink jersey of overall leader on the podium. With Aru struggling with the stage, Contador increased his overall lead over the Italian and took a massive step towards his second Giro d’Italia triumph. An epic 16th stage was won by fellow Mikel Landa in a time of 5hr 2min 51sec, with Contador settling for third place at 38sec behind on the wheel of Steven Kruijswijk.

displayImages.caption: Stage 17 Tirano to Lugano, Switzerland (134km) The Giro leader has international appeal. Photograph: Tim de Waele/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Stage 17 Tirano to Lugano, Switzerland (134km) The Giro leader has international appeal
displayImages.cleanCaption: Stage 17 Tirano to Lugano, Switzerland (134km) The Giro leader has international appeal.

displayImages.caption: Not everyone sees the appeal of Contador or the Giro, mind. Photograph: Claudio Peri/EPA
displayImages.altText: Not everyone can see the appeal of the Giro
displayImages.cleanCaption: Not everyone sees the appeal of Contador or the Giro, mind.

displayImages.caption: Sacha Modolo, centre, won the sprint for the line. The top of the general classification was unchanged, with Contador leading by 4min 2sec from Mikel Landa after finishing safely in 23rd. Photograph: Tim de Waele/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Sacha Modolo, centre, won the sprint for the line.  The top of the general classification was unchanged, with Contador leading by 4min 2sec from Mikel Landa after finishing safely in 23rd place
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sacha Modolo, centre, won the sprint for the line. The top of the general classification was unchanged, with Contador leading by 4min 2sec from Mikel Landa after finishing safely in 23rd.

displayImages.caption: Stage 18 Melide (Switzerland) to Verbania (170km) The peloton makes its way through a narrow street. Photograph: Tim de Waele/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Stage 18 Melide (Switzerland) to Verbania The peloton makes its way through a narrow street
displayImages.cleanCaption: Stage 18 Melide (Switzerland) to Verbania (170km) The peloton makes its way through a narrow street.

displayImages.caption: Rigoberto Uran in action. Photograph: Tim de Waele/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Rigoberto Uran in action
displayImages.cleanCaption: Rigoberto Uran in action.

displayImages.caption: Philippe Gilbert checks on his rivals before securing his second stage win from a breakaway after a spine-tingling descent of the final climb, the Monte Ologno. Photograph: Tim de Waele/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Philippe Gilbert checks on his rivals ahead of securing his second stage win from a breakaway after a spine-tingling descent of the final climb, the Monte Ologno

displayImages.altText: The peloton on a descent

displayImages.caption: Aru, after struggling in the previous mountain stages, regained strength and won the stage. He also regained second place overall as Landa and Contador finished in a group more than a minute behind him. Photograph: Reuters
displayImages.altText: Fabio Aru, after struggling in the previous mountain stages, regained strength and won the stage. He also regained second place overall as Landa and Contador finished in a group more than a minute behind him

displayImages.caption: Stage 20 Saint-Vincent to Sestriere (196km) Riders are applauded by a local as they pass. Photograph: Claudio Peri/AP
displayImages.altText: Stage 20 Saint-Vincent to Sestriere (196km) Riders are applauded by a local as they pass
displayImages.cleanCaption: Stage 20 Saint-Vincent to Sestriere (196km) Riders are applauded by a local as they pass.

displayImages.caption: Riders climb the Colle delle Finestre. Photograph: Reuters
displayImages.altText: Riders climb Colle delle Finestre mountain
displayImages.cleanCaption: Riders climb the Colle delle Finestre.

displayImages.caption: Contador climbs the Colle delle Finestre. He lost touch with his main rivals in the penultimate climb, up the narrow dirt roads, but retained the overall leader’s pink jersey. Photograph: Reuters
displayImages.altText: Alberto Contador climbs Colle delle Finestre mountain. Contador lost touch with his main rivals in the penultimate climb, up the narrow dirt roads to the Colle delle Finestre, but retained the overall leader's pink jersey
displayImages.cleanCaption: Contador climbs the Colle delle Finestre. He lost touch with his main rivals in the penultimate climb, up the narrow dirt roads, but retained the overall leader’s pink jersey.

displayImages.caption: Aru celebrates as he crosses the finish line to win the 20th stage, his second stage win in a row. The Italian is now 2min 2sec behind Contador but barring a crash in Sunday’s final stage, the Spaniard is poised to win the Giro d’Italia. Photograph: Mauro Ujetto/Demotix/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Fabio Aru celebrates as he crosses the finish line to win the 20th stage, his second stage win in a row.  The Italian is now 2min 2sec behind Contador but barring a crash in Sunday’s final stage, the Spaniard is poised to win the Giro d’Italia
displayImages.cleanCaption: Aru celebrates as he crosses the finish line to win the 20th stage, his second stage win in a row. The Italian is now 2min 2sec behind Contador but barring a crash in Sunday’s final stage, the Spaniard is poised to win the Giro d’Italia.

displayImages.caption: Stage 21 Torino to Milano (185km) The pack of riders ride through the Italian countryside. Photograph: Reuters
displayImages.altText: Stage 21 Torino to Milano (185km) The pack of riders ride through the Italian countryside
displayImages.cleanCaption: Stage 21 Torino to Milano (185km) The pack of riders ride through the Italian countryside.

displayImages.caption: Contador holds a glass of sparkling wine as the riders head towards Milan. Photograph: Claudio Peri/AP
displayImages.altText: Alberto Contador holds a glass of sparkling wine as the riders head towards Milan
displayImages.cleanCaption: Contador holds a glass of sparkling wine as the riders head towards Milan.

displayImages.caption: Contador celebrates as he crosses the finish line to win the 98th Giro d’Italia. The Spaniard, who won the three-week race for the first time in 2008, became the second rider after Bernard Hinault to have won the three grand tours (Tour de France, Giro, Vuelta) at least twice. Photograph: Luk Benies/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Contador celebrates as he crosses the finish line to win the 98th Giro d'Italia. The Spaniard, who won the three-week race for the first time in 2008, became the second rider after Frenchman Bernard Hinault to have won the three grand tours (Tour de France, Giro, Vuelta) at least twice
displayImages.cleanCaption: Contador celebrates as he crosses the finish line to win the 98th Giro d’Italia. The Spaniard, who won the three-week race for the first time in 2008, became the second rider after Bernard Hinault to have won the three grand tours (Tour de France, Giro, Vuelta) at least twice.

displayImages.caption: Contador enhanced his status as one of the greatest grand tour riders with second Giro d’Italia title and is looking to become the first rider to achieve a rare Giro/Tour de France double since the late Marco Pantani in 1998. Photograph: NurPhoto/Rex Shutterstock
displayImages.altText: Contador enhanced his status as one of the greatest grand tour riders with second Giro d’Italia title and is looking to become the first rider to achieve a rare Giro/Tour de France double since the late Marco Pantani in 1998
displayImages.cleanCaption: Contador enhanced his status as one of the greatest grand tour riders with second Giro d’Italia title and is looking to become the first rider to achieve a rare Giro/Tour de France double since the late Marco Pantani in 1998.
